%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%% LyX specific LaTeX commands.
\providecommand{\LyX}{\texorpdfstring{\ensureascii{%
  L\kern-.1667em\lower.25em\hbox{Y}\kern-.125emX\@}}{LyX}}

%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%% Textclass specific LaTeX commands.
\usepackage{sagetex}
\newcommand{\centerplot}[1]{\begin{center}\sageplot[width=10cm][pdf]{#1}\end{center}}
\newcommand{\sageeqninline}[1]{$ \sage{#1} $}
\newcommand{\sageeqndisplay}[1]{\[ \sage{#1} \]}
%
% The preamble inserted by the Lyx Notebook module for Sage.
%
\usepackage{listings}
\usepackage{verbatim} % to make comment blocks for non-printing
\usepackage{ifthen} % etoolbox is apparently more modern, but ifthen works fine
\usepackage{color}
\usepackage{marginnote} % for small labels to right of cells
\usepackage{needspace} % prevent bad line breaks hopefully
\usepackage{graphicx} % to rotate the small labels to the right of cells
\usepackage{setspace} % needed for \setstretch, which may not be needed
% \usepackage[T1]{fontenc} % needed for some fonts if not already loaded
\usepackage{textcomp} % needed for upquote=true option and fonts like beramono
% \usepackage{courier} % for lack of bold in Computer Modern typewriter font
% \usepackage{palatino}
%
% Just tell users in docs to select luximono or beramono for tt font, from
% lyx document menu, if they have it installed.
%\IfFileExists{luximono.sty}{
%   \usepackage[scaled]{luximono} % recommended by some, not preloaded
%}
%{}
% \usepackage[scaled]{beramono} % bitstream vera mono
% \usepackage[scaled]{inconsolata}

% set some global formatting options to their default values
\def\lyxNotebookNoColor{false} % use color unless this def is overridden
\def\lyxNotebookNoCellLabels{false} % put small label on cells unless set true
\def\lyxNotebookNeedspaceLabelValue{4\baselineskip}


%
% Header stuff for the Sage Init cells.
%
% Define the function to turn off printing (just make same as verbatim comment)
% for the inset specifier Sage and basic cell type Init
% Note at least some EOL comments required below or extra space inserted in text.
\def\lyxNotebookPrintingIsOffInitSage{false}
\def\lyxNotebookPrintOffInitSage{%
   \def\lyxNotebookPrintingIsOffInitSage{true}%
   \let\oldLyxNotebookCellInitSage\lyxNotebookCellInitSage%
   \let\lyxNotebookCellInitSage=\comment%
   \let\oldEndlyxNotebookCellInitSage\endlyxNotebookCellInitSage%
   \let\endlyxNotebookCellInitSage=\endcomment%
}%

% Define the function to turn printing back on if it has been turned off
% for the inset specifier Sage and basic cell type Init
% Note at least some EOL comments required below or extra space inserted in text.
\def\lyxNotebookPrintOnInitSage{%
   \ifthenelse{\equal{\lyxNotebookPrintingIsOffInitSage}{true}}{%
      \let\lyxNotebookCellInitSage=\oldLyxNotebookCellInitSage%
      \let\endlyxNotebookCellInitSage=\oldEndlyxNotebookCellInitSage%
      \def\lyxNotebookPrintingIsOffInitSage{false}%
   }%
   {}%
}%

% Build up the general printing off/on commands by adding commands for the
% inset specifier Sage and basic cell type Init
% (Note expandafter is used to avoid recursion problems; using e.g.
% \let\oldegg\egg and then using oldegg on the r.h.s. should also work.)
\ifthenelse{\isundefined{\lyxNotebookPrintOff}}{\def\lyxNotebookPrintOff{}}{}
\expandafter\def\expandafter\lyxNotebookPrintOff\expandafter{\lyxNotebookPrintOff\lyxNotebookPrintOffInitSage}
\ifthenelse{\isundefined{\lyxNotebookPrintOn}}{\def\lyxNotebookPrintOn{}}{}
\expandafter\def\expandafter\lyxNotebookPrintOn\expandafter{\lyxNotebookPrintOn\lyxNotebookPrintOnInitSage}

%
% Header stuff for the Sage Standard cells.
%
% Define the function to turn off printing (just make same as verbatim comment)
% for the inset specifier Sage and basic cell type Standard
% Note at least some EOL comments required below or extra space inserted in text.
\def\lyxNotebookPrintingIsOffStandardSage{false}
\def\lyxNotebookPrintOffStandardSage{%
   \def\lyxNotebookPrintingIsOffStandardSage{true}%
   \let\oldLyxNotebookCellStandardSage\lyxNotebookCellStandardSage%
   \let\lyxNotebookCellStandardSage=\comment%
   \let\oldEndlyxNotebookCellStandardSage\endlyxNotebookCellStandardSage%
   \let\endlyxNotebookCellStandardSage=\endcomment%
}%

% Define the function to turn printing back on if it has been turned off
% for the inset specifier Sage and basic cell type Standard
% Note at least some EOL comments required below or extra space inserted in text.
\def\lyxNotebookPrintOnStandardSage{%
   \ifthenelse{\equal{\lyxNotebookPrintingIsOffStandardSage}{true}}{%
      \let\lyxNotebookCellStandardSage=\oldLyxNotebookCellStandardSage%
      \let\endlyxNotebookCellStandardSage=\oldEndlyxNotebookCellStandardSage%
      \def\lyxNotebookPrintingIsOffStandardSage{false}%
   }%
   {}%
}%

% Build up the general printing off/on commands by adding commands for the
% inset specifier Sage and basic cell type Standard
% (Note expandafter is used to avoid recursion problems; using e.g.
% \let\oldegg\egg and then using oldegg on the r.h.s. should also work.)
\ifthenelse{\isundefined{\lyxNotebookPrintOff}}{\def\lyxNotebookPrintOff{}}{}
\expandafter\def\expandafter\lyxNotebookPrintOff\expandafter{\lyxNotebookPrintOff\lyxNotebookPrintOffStandardSage}
\ifthenelse{\isundefined{\lyxNotebookPrintOn}}{\def\lyxNotebookPrintOn{}}{}
\expandafter\def\expandafter\lyxNotebookPrintOn\expandafter{\lyxNotebookPrintOn\lyxNotebookPrintOnStandardSage}

%
% Header stuff for the Sage Output cells.
%
% Define the function to turn off printing (just make same as verbatim comment)
% for the inset specifier Sage and basic cell type Output
% Note at least some EOL comments required below or extra space inserted in text.
\def\lyxNotebookPrintingIsOffOutputSage{false}
\def\lyxNotebookPrintOffOutputSage{%
   \def\lyxNotebookPrintingIsOffOutputSage{true}%
   \let\oldLyxNotebookCellOutputSage\lyxNotebookCellOutputSage%
   \let\lyxNotebookCellOutputSage=\comment%
   \let\oldEndlyxNotebookCellOutputSage\endlyxNotebookCellOutputSage%
   \let\endlyxNotebookCellOutputSage=\endcomment%
}%

% Define the function to turn printing back on if it has been turned off
% for the inset specifier Sage and basic cell type Output
% Note at least some EOL comments required below or extra space inserted in text.
\def\lyxNotebookPrintOnOutputSage{%
   \ifthenelse{\equal{\lyxNotebookPrintingIsOffOutputSage}{true}}{%
      \let\lyxNotebookCellOutputSage=\oldLyxNotebookCellOutputSage%
      \let\endlyxNotebookCellOutputSage=\oldEndlyxNotebookCellOutputSage%
      \def\lyxNotebookPrintingIsOffOutputSage{false}%
   }%
   {}%
}%

% Build up the general printing off/on commands by adding commands for the
% inset specifier Sage and basic cell type Output
% (Note expandafter is used to avoid recursion problems; using e.g.
% \let\oldegg\egg and then using oldegg on the r.h.s. should also work.)
\ifthenelse{\isundefined{\lyxNotebookPrintOff}}{\def\lyxNotebookPrintOff{}}{}
\expandafter\def\expandafter\lyxNotebookPrintOff\expandafter{\lyxNotebookPrintOff\lyxNotebookPrintOffOutputSage}
\ifthenelse{\isundefined{\lyxNotebookPrintOn}}{\def\lyxNotebookPrintOn{}}{}
\expandafter\def\expandafter\lyxNotebookPrintOn\expandafter{\lyxNotebookPrintOn\lyxNotebookPrintOnOutputSage}

% Latex code for Sage cells from interpreter_spec.py
%
% Define some of the variables described in the documentation to set the font
% size and family.  These definitions should preferably be used below instead of
% the values themselves (so users can easily redefine these default values
% from their preamble).
\def\lyxNotebookFontSize{\footnotesize}
\def\lyxNotebookColorCodeFontFamily{\ttfamily}
\def\lyxNotebookColorOutputFontFamily{\ttfamily}
\def\lyxNotebookNoColorCodeFontFamily{\sffamily}
\def\lyxNotebookNoColorOutputFontFamily{\sffamily}
\def\lyxNotebookLabelFormat{\ttfamily\tiny\bfseries}

% define some colors to use
\definecolor{gray9}{gray}{0.5}
\definecolor{darkGray9}{gray}{0.05} % almost black, for normal text with colors
\definecolor{green9}{rgb}{0,0.6,0}
\definecolor{darkerGreen9}{rgb}{0,0.3,0}
\definecolor{darkerRed9}{rgb}{0.6,0.0,0.0}
\definecolor{brightRed9}{rgb}{1.0,0.0,0.0}
\definecolor{yellowGold9}{rgb}{0.7,0.5,0.0}
\definecolor{blue9}{rgb}{0.20,0.20,1.0}
\definecolor{darkerBlue9}{rgb}{0.20,0.20,0.60}
\definecolor{pinkRed9}{rgb}{0.9,0.2,0.4}
\definecolor{turquoise9}{rgb}{0.0,0.6,1.0}
\definecolor{bluishPurple9}{rgb}{0.2,0.0,1.0}
\definecolor{purple9}{rgb}{0.4,0.0,1.0}

%
% Now define the Listings styles for Lyx Notebook Sage,
% setting the language to python (which will be replaced by the
% listings_language field of the general spec.  Note the default frame
% conventions are defined here (since the general code format for Init
% and Standard cells doesn't differ).
%

% define style lyxNotebookNoColorInitSage
\lstdefinestyle{lyxNotebookNoColorInitSage}{
   language=python,
   % general_listings_code_format
   showlines=true, % keep blank lines at end of listing blocks
   sensitive=true,
   morecomment=[s]{"""}{"""},
   %alsoletter={1234567890}, % numbers like letters
   % but in otherkeywords causes it to highlight in strings and comments
   %otherkeywords={(,),[,],\{,\},@,\,,:,.,`,=,;,+=,-=,*=,/=,//=,%=,&=,|=,^=,>>=,<<=,**=} % delimiters in Python
   %otherkeywords={1,2,3,4,5,6,7,8,9,0,-,=,+,[,],(,),\{,\},:,*,!},
   %
   % The keywords need to be redefined to reset the "import" color.
   % See http://docs.python.org/reference/lexical_analysis.html
   keywords=[1]{and,as,assert,break,class,continue,def,del,elif,else,%
                except,exec,finally,for,global,if,in,is,lambda,not,or,%
                pass,print,raise,return,try,while,with,yield},
   morekeywords=[2]{True, False, None, self, NotImplemented, Ellipsis,%
                    __debug__, quit, exit, copyright, license, credits},
   morekeywords=[3]{from,import}, % note "as" is also in "with" and "except"
   %mathescape=true,
   % Linebreak symbols: arrows look nice but mess up the frame
   % prebreak=\raisebox{0ex}[0ex][0ex]{\ensuremath{\hookleftarrow}},
   % postbreak=\raisebox{0ex}[0ex][0ex]{\ensuremath{\diagdown}},
   % Use backslash instead:
   prebreak=\bf\textbackslash,
   showstringspaces=false,
   breaklines=true,
   breakatwhitespace=true,
   breakindent=1.5em,
   breakautoindent=true,
   % fancyvrb=true, % causes problems, even with all but lang commented out
   % numbers=left, numberstyle=\tiny, stepnumber=1, numbersep=6pt,
   % columns=flexible,
   % columns=fullflexible, % good with monospace font, & more chars per line
   columns=fixed, % fewer chars per line, but keeps extra spaces inserted
   % linewidth=\linewidth, % default seems to work better
   upquote=true, 
   % non_color_listings_code_format
   basicstyle=\lyxNotebookFontSize%
              \setstretch{1}%
              \lyxNotebookNoColorCodeFontFamily%
              \color{darkGray9},
   stringstyle=\ttfamily, % use ttfamily for strings at least
   %commentstyle=\upshape, % don't use the default italic comments
   commentstyle=\slshape\color[rgb]{0.3,0.3,0.3}, % slanted gray
   %commentstyle=\itshape,
   keywordstyle=[1]\bfseries,
   keywordstyle=[2]\bfseries,
   keywordstyle=[3]\bfseries, 
   frame=TbLR
}

% define style lyxNotebookNoColorStandardSage
\lstdefinestyle{lyxNotebookNoColorStandardSage}{
   style=lyxNotebookNoColorInitSage,
   frame=tblr
}

% define style lyxNotebookColorInitSage
\lstdefinestyle{lyxNotebookColorInitSage}{
   language=python,
   % general_listings_code_format
   showlines=true, % keep blank lines at end of listing blocks
   sensitive=true,
   morecomment=[s]{"""}{"""},
   %alsoletter={1234567890}, % numbers like letters
   % but in otherkeywords causes it to highlight in strings and comments
   %otherkeywords={(,),[,],\{,\},@,\,,:,.,`,=,;,+=,-=,*=,/=,//=,%=,&=,|=,^=,>>=,<<=,**=} % delimiters in Python
   %otherkeywords={1,2,3,4,5,6,7,8,9,0,-,=,+,[,],(,),\{,\},:,*,!},
   %
   % The keywords need to be redefined to reset the "import" color.
   % See http://docs.python.org/reference/lexical_analysis.html
   keywords=[1]{and,as,assert,break,class,continue,def,del,elif,else,%
                except,exec,finally,for,global,if,in,is,lambda,not,or,%
                pass,print,raise,return,try,while,with,yield},
   morekeywords=[2]{True, False, None, self, NotImplemented, Ellipsis,%
                    __debug__, quit, exit, copyright, license, credits},
   morekeywords=[3]{from,import}, % note "as" is also in "with" and "except"
   %mathescape=true,
   % Linebreak symbols: arrows look nice but mess up the frame
   % prebreak=\raisebox{0ex}[0ex][0ex]{\ensuremath{\hookleftarrow}},
   % postbreak=\raisebox{0ex}[0ex][0ex]{\ensuremath{\diagdown}},
   % Use backslash instead:
   prebreak=\bf\textbackslash,
   showstringspaces=false,
   breaklines=true,
   breakatwhitespace=true,
   breakindent=1.5em,
   breakautoindent=true,
   % fancyvrb=true, % causes problems, even with all but lang commented out
   % numbers=left, numberstyle=\tiny, stepnumber=1, numbersep=6pt,
   % columns=flexible,
   % columns=fullflexible, % good with monospace font, & more chars per line
   columns=fixed, % fewer chars per line, but keeps extra spaces inserted
   % linewidth=\linewidth, % default seems to work better
   upquote=true, 
   % color_listings_code_format
   basicstyle=\lyxNotebookFontSize%
              \setstretch{1}%
              \lyxNotebookColorCodeFontFamily%
              \color{darkGray9},
   rulecolor=\color{black}, % may be needed for line-broken color lines
   %identifierstyle=\color{darkGray9},
   stringstyle=\ttfamily\color{blue9},
   %stringstyle=\ttfamily\color{darkerBlue9},
   %stringstyle=\ttfamily\color{green9},
   %commentstyle=\upshape\color{green9},
   %commentstyle=\slshape\color{darkerGreen9},
   commentstyle=\slshape\color[rgb]{0.0,0.4,0.0},
   keywordstyle=[1]\bfseries\color{darkerRed9},
   keywordstyle=[2]\bfseries\color{pinkRed9},
   keywordstyle=[3]\bfseries\color{yellowGold9}, 
   frame=TbLR
}

% define style lyxNotebookColorStandardSage
\lstdefinestyle{lyxNotebookColorStandardSage}{
   style=lyxNotebookColorInitSage,
   frame=tblr
}

% define style lyxNotebookColorNonEvalSage
\lstdefinestyle{lyxNotebookColorNonEvalSage}{
   style=lyxNotebookColorInitSage,
   frame=TBLR
}

% define style lyxNotebookNoColorNonEvalSage
\lstdefinestyle{lyxNotebookNoColorNonEvalSage}{
   style=lyxNotebookNoColorInitSage,
   frame=TBLR
}

% define style lyxNotebookNoColorOutputSage
\lstdefinestyle{lyxNotebookNoColorOutputSage}{
   language=,
   % general_listings_output_format
   showlines=true, % keep blank lines at end
   %mathescape=true,
   showstringspaces=false,
   breaklines=true,
   breakatwhitespace=true,
   breakindent=1.5em, breakautoindent=true,
   % Linebreaks: see comments earlier for code cells; arrows mess up frames.
   % prebreak=\raisebox{0ex}[0ex][0ex]{\ensuremath{\hookleftarrow}},
   % postbreak=\raisebox{0ex}[0ex][0ex]{\ensuremath{\diagdown}},
   % Use backslash instead.
   prebreak=\bf\textbackslash,
   % linewidth=\linewidth, % default seems to work better
   % numbers=left, numberstyle=\tiny, stepnumber=1, numbersep=6pt,
   % columns=flexible, %
   % columns=fullflexible, % good with monospace font, & more chars per line
   columns=fixed, % fewer chars per line, but keeps extra spaces inserted
   aboveskip=\doubleskipamount, % make abut the cell above, a calulated value
   upquote=true, 
   % non_color_listings_output_format
   % set the font to a gray color
   basicstyle=\lyxNotebookFontSize%
              \setstretch{1}%
              \lyxNotebookNoColorOutputFontFamily%
              \color[rgb]{0.2,0.2,0.2}, 
   frame=tblr
}

% define lyxNotebookColorOutputSage
\lstdefinestyle{lyxNotebookColorOutputSage}{
   language=,
   % general_listings_output_format
   showlines=true, % keep blank lines at end
   %mathescape=true,
   showstringspaces=false,
   breaklines=true,
   breakatwhitespace=true,
   breakindent=1.5em, breakautoindent=true,
   % Linebreaks: see comments earlier for code cells; arrows mess up frames.
   % prebreak=\raisebox{0ex}[0ex][0ex]{\ensuremath{\hookleftarrow}},
   % postbreak=\raisebox{0ex}[0ex][0ex]{\ensuremath{\diagdown}},
   % Use backslash instead.
   prebreak=\bf\textbackslash,
   % linewidth=\linewidth, % default seems to work better
   % numbers=left, numberstyle=\tiny, stepnumber=1, numbersep=6pt,
   % columns=flexible, %
   % columns=fullflexible, % good with monospace font, & more chars per line
   columns=fixed, % fewer chars per line, but keeps extra spaces inserted
   aboveskip=\doubleskipamount, % make abut the cell above, a calulated value
   upquote=true, 
   % color_listings_output_format
   % set the font to a gray color
   basicstyle=\lyxNotebookFontSize%
              \setstretch{1}
              \lyxNotebookColorOutputFontFamily
              \color[rgb]{0.2,0.2,0.2}, 
   frame=tblr
}




\makeatother

\begin{document}
\title{Exemple d'intégration de \LyX{} à Sage}
\author{\selectlanguage{french}%
Original par : Murat Yildizoglu}
\author{Modifié par : Thomas Coffee }
\date{March 30, 2012/ 7 juin, 2019}
\maketitle
\selectlanguage{american}%

\section{Présentation}

Sage (\href{http://sagemath.org}{http://sagemath.org}) is an open
source computer algebra system that integrates a wide variety of open
source mathematics software, with the mission of ''creating a viable
free open source alternative to Magma, Maple, Mathematica, and Matlab.''
Sage uses Python as the glue for integrating nearly 100 open source
packages for mathematics, programming, and visualization. Sage speaks
\LaTeX{} and can be used for literate programming that mixes normal
text with Sage instructions, directly including results in PS/PDF
files. The \texttt{sagetex.sty} package allows the input of Sage instructions
in a \LaTeX{} file (in a manner similar to Sweave and R-Project).

The file sage.module provides the following Sage{}\TeX{} elements
in \LyX :
\begin{itemize}
\item \texttt{sageblock} and \texttt{sagesilent} environments for blocks
of code made visible or invisible in the final document, respectively
\item \texttt{sageplot} and \texttt{sageplotcenter}\footnote{a customized call to \texttt{sageplot} defined in the sage.module
file; you can define similar environments with different options to
conveniently generate multiple plots of different styles} environments that can be used for plotting code inside a Figure float
\item \texttt{sagecommand} and \texttt{sageinline} insets\footnote{accessible via the menu item Insert >\textcompwordmark > Custom Insets}
that can be used inline, where results of the latter appear in math
mode
\item \texttt{sagedisplay} environment, whose results appear in display
math mode\footnote{you can define similar environments in sage.module to support other
math environments}
\end{itemize}
The Sage{}\TeX{} commands \texttt{\textbackslash sage} and \texttt{\textbackslash sageplot},
along with other custom commands defined in sage.module, can also
be used as ERT. This can be useful in math mode when results from
Sage should be combined seamlessly with other equation components.
Note that \LyX 's special handling of math mode formatting can cause
problems for some Sage input: for this reason, it may be necessary
to assign a result to a named variable using a \texttt{sagesilent}
environment and include the variable by name in ERT where the result
should appear.

When a Sage{}\TeX{} document \texttt{mydocument.tex} is compiled with
(pdf)latex, it automatically generates a Sage file \texttt{mydocument.sage}
that can be run through Sage using the command \texttt{sage mydocument.sage}.
This compiles the results of the Sage instructions and a supplementary
run through (pdf)latex includes these results (computations, plots,
etc.) in the final document. The files included with this example
provide a basic capability to combine this functionality with \LyX ,
which you can extend to meet your specific needs.

Using this module, to compile a document with embedded Sage code one
must view the output as ``PDF (pdflatex+sagetex)'', located by default
under ``Other Formats.'' To update only the \LaTeX{} without updating
any results from Sage, one can use the default output format ``PDF
(pdflatex)''. This default can be changed in the included \texttt{preferences}
file.

If you are working under GNU/Linux, the included shell script \texttt{setup.sh}
can be customized to place the necessary components where they belong.
This assumes you have already installed and tested \LyX{} and Sage
independently, and includes the necessary commands to include Sage{}\TeX{}
in a common \LaTeX{} installation.\footnote{based on \href{http://www.sagemath.org/doc/installation/sagetex.html}{http://www.sagemath.org/doc/installation/sagetex.html}}
After establishing the configuration, you will need to run Tools >\textcompwordmark >
Reconfigure from the \LyX{} menu. This configuration has been successfully
tested using the following setup:
\begin{itemize}
\item Ubuntu 11.10 x86\_64
\item \LyX{} 2.0.0 with \TeX Live 2009-13 (but should work with \LyX{} 1.6+)
\item Sage 4.8 {[}2012-01-20{]}
\end{itemize}
Note that in earlier versions of Sage, Sage{}\TeX{} may produce files
with extension \texttt{.sage} rather than \texttt{.sagetex.sage}.
You may need to modify the \texttt{preferences} and \texttt{compile-pdf-sage.sh}
files accordingly.

\section{Exemples}

Sage peut faire du \LaTeX : \sageeqninline{matrix([[1, 2], [3,4]])^2}

\selectlanguage{french}%
\begin{figure}
\centerplot{plot(sin(x), -pi, pi), axes=True,frame=True,figsize=4,fontsize=5,gridlines="major"}

\caption{Fonction sinus}\label{fig:Test-de-figure}
\end{figure}

\selectlanguage{english}%
Sage{}\TeX{} peut inclure des blocks pour définir et calculer des
éléments. Dans ce cas, les blocks ne sont mis en forme dans le document,
puisqu'on utilise \texttt{sagesilent} environment. On déclare $x$
comme variable et $y=x^{2}+5x+2$.
\selectlanguage{american}%
\begin{sagesilent}
x=var('x')
y=x^2+5*x+2
\end{sagesilent}

On peut maintenant calculer une équation avec une inconnue $x$: la
racine de l'équation $x^{2}+5x+2$ est obtenue alors par le calcul
avec Sage :
\sageeqndisplay{solve(y,x)}

Another equation, third degree of $x$ this time: roots of $x^{3}-10$
are: 
\sageeqndisplay{solve(x^3-10,x)}

A system of two equations:
\begin{sageblock}
x,y=var('x y')
z=solve([x+y==6,x-y==4],x,y)
\end{sageblock}

The roots of the system\foreignlanguage{french}{
\[
\begin{array}{ccc}
x+y & = & 6\\
x-y & = & 4
\end{array}
\]
are given by:}
\sageeqndisplay{z}

Sage can do differentiation:
\begin{sageblock}
y=sin(x^2)
\end{sageblock}

\selectlanguage{french}%
\begin{center}
$\dfrac{\partial^{4}y}{\partial x^{4}}=\sage{diff(y,x,4)}$
\par\end{center}

\selectlanguage{american}%
Sage can also do integrals:\foreignlanguage{french}{ 
\[
\int_{0}^{1}\frac{x}{x^{2}+1}
\]
}is given by \sageeqninline{integral(x/(x^2+1),x,0,1)}.

Sage can solve differential equations: we declare a variable $t$,
a function of $t$, $x(t)$ and a differential equation\foreignlanguage{french}{
\[
\frac{dx}{dt}+x-1=0
\]
}
\begin{sageblock}
t = var('t')
x = function('x')(t)
DE = diff(x, t) + x - 1
\end{sageblock}

We can now solve the equation: 

\begin{center}
$x(t)=\sage{desolve(DE,[x,t])}$
\par\end{center}

Traduit par : Henri Girard, 7 juin 2019
\end{document}
